verses.text: God, give Your judgment to the king, and Your righteousness to the king’s son.
verses.comment: This is a prayer for the king, likely Solomon, asking God to grant wisdom and righteousness. The reference to the king’s son hints at a royal line, prefiguring the eternal kingship fulfilled in Christ (see Luke 1:32-33).

verses.text: He will judge Your people with righteousness, and Your poor with justice.
verses.comment: The king, as God's representative, brings just rule, especially to the poor—a model that foreshadows the justice Christ brings (Isaiah 11:4).

verses.text: Let the mountains bring peace to the people, and the hills, righteousness.
verses.comment: Symbolic language indicating that all creation shares in the blessings of a just ruler. Mountains and hills are often used to represent stability and the universal scope of peace.

verses.text: May he defend the cause of the poor among the people, save the children of the needy, and crush the oppressor.
verses.comment: A righteous king protects the weakest, mirroring Christ’s compassion and His ultimate overthrow of evil (Luke 4:18).

verses.text: May he live as long as the sun shines, and as long as the moon, through all generations.
verses.comment: The prayer for an everlasting reign anticipates the eternal kingship of the Messiah (see Luke 1:33; Revelation 11:15).

verses.text: May he be like rain falling on the mown grass, like showers that water the earth.
verses.comment: The reign of the king refreshes and gives life, just as grace makes the soul flourish (see John 4:14).

verses.text: In his days the righteous will flourish, and peace will abound till the moon is no more.
verses.comment: Ultimate fulfillment in Jesus, the Prince of Peace, whose kingdom brings endless righteousness and peace (cf. Isaiah 9:7; Matthew 5:9).

verses.text: He will rule from sea to sea, and from the River to the ends of the earth.
verses.comment: The king’s reign is universal, prefiguring Christ’s authority over all nations (see Matthew 28:18-19).

verses.text: Those who dwell in the desert will bow before him, and his enemies will lick the dust.
verses.comment: Images of submission show the king’s complete triumph. 'Lick the dust' alludes to Genesis 3:14 and signifies ultimate defeat.

verses.text: The kings of Tarshish and of distant shores will bring tribute; the kings of Sheba and Seba will offer gifts.
verses.comment: Nations bringing gifts finds fulfillment in the magi visiting Christ, signaling the recognition of His kingship by the Gentiles.

verses.text: All kings will bow down before him; all nations will serve him.
verses.comment: A prophecy of universal submission, echoed in Philippians 2:10-11, where every knee bows to Jesus.

verses.text: For he will deliver the needy who cry out, the afflicted and those with no one to help.
verses.comment: Highlights God’s preference for the poor and afflicted—a theme Jesus emphasized (Matthew 5:3; Luke 4:18).

verses.text: He will have pity on the weak and the needy, and will save the lives of the needy.
verses.comment: Mercy is a royal quality, perfected in Christ, who saves both physically and spiritually (John 6:35, Luke 19:10).

verses.text: He will redeem them from oppression and violence, and precious will their blood be in his sight.
verses.comment: God values each person, especially the innocent. This verse foreshadows the redemption won through Christ’s precious blood (1 Peter 1:19).

verses.text: May he live, and may they give him gold from Sheba; may prayers be made for him continually, and may people bless him all day long.
verses.comment: Prayer for the king’s well-being and continuous blessing; the idea of praying for leaders still resonates in Christian worship and intercession.

verses.text: May abundance of grain be in the land on the tops of the mountains; its fruit will wave like Lebanon, and people will blossom from the cities like the grass of the earth.
verses.comment: Imagery of superabundant blessing connotes a fruitful reign, symbolizing God’s overflowing grace.

verses.text: May his name endure forever; may his name increase as long as the sun shines. All nations will be blessed through him, and they will call him blessed.
verses.comment: God’s covenant with Abraham is echoed here—'all nations blessed' through the royal line, ultimately in Christ (Galatians 3:16).

verses.text: Blessed be the LORD God, the God of Israel, who alone does wondrous things.
verses.comment: Doxology, directing praise to God alone as the source of all good and wondrous works.

verses.text: Blessed be His glorious name forever; may all the earth be filled with His glory! Amen and Amen.
verses.comment: 'All the earth filled with His glory' is both a current reality and a prophetic hope, mirrored in the Lord’s Prayer (“Thy kingdom come, Thy will be done on earth as it is in heaven”).

verses.text: The prayers of David, the son of Jesse, are ended.
verses.comment: This concluding note marks the end of a collection of Davidic prayers. Tradition assigns much of the Psalter to David, but recognizes others (like Solomon) contributing. The seamless unity of the psalms points toward a broader, continuing tradition of worship and intercession.
